text: the creation of the first nuclear bomb
by scientist J robert Oppenheimer
is the unlikely inspiration for dr.
atomic an offer written by Pulitzer
Prize winning composer John Adams in
2005 the atomic bomb really is in a
sense the constellation of everything
America stands for both what makes us
great and what makes us a problem in the
world in a new production that will
premiere at the Med on October 13th
dr. atomic tracks the countdown to the
explosion of the first atomic bomb near
Los Alamos New Mexico home to the
Manhattan Project in the summer of 1945
as an opera composer Adams is often
drawn to historical moments that
pinpoint moral complexities dr. atomic
represents American ingenuity principles
of freedom the fight against fascism but
also the onerous responsibility of
having been the first country to develop
a weapon that can destroy all human life
and also having this terrible guilt of
being the only country that's actually
used and clear
baritone Gerald Finley returns the title
role he performed at the operas 2005
premiere in San Francisco
the Mets new production is helmed by
first time offered director penny
Wolcott coming from a film background
when one of the great challenges for me
was having to make everything happen
inside a box and I found the constraints
both kind of incredibly frustrating
initially and fantastically liberating
and on stage in a way you can be kind of
deliriously inventive and we started
with certain images of some cloth
mountains from a polish production in
the 60s and I had an image of a
sculpture made by an English sculptor
called cornelia parker his called cold
dark matter where she blew up a shed and
then collected all the little bits and
pieces that had lain around and
suspended them from was so there was a
sense of seeing something in the middle
of an explosion
the restaging features sets designed by
julien crouch that mirror the periodic
table of elements as well as video
projections and animations of scientific
equations I know absolutely nothing
about science so I've put several things
in there to help sort of imbecilic
people like me and understand things
better I suppose
wall clock who has never directed for
the stage was inspired by the scientists
at the heart of the story one of the
things was discovering how interesting
these people were and and how exciting
this project was and there was a huge
amount of debate about the ethics of
what they were doing
the libretto by Peter Sellers is a
collage from documentary sources history
books and poetry
kitti Oppenheimer who is the voice of
the feminine moral consciousness largely
speaks through the poetry of Muriel
Rukeyser who was a mid-century American
poet but despite all the changes in the
production the Opera Center remains the
bomb and its impact one of the amazing
things that I think dr. Tommy does is to
make you think about something that you
believed that you understood before and
I think that's one of the great things
about music is that there's a kind of
beauty in the sort of horror of it as
well
